column4: hi. im having a trouble with wireless on my ubuntu laptop. the wireless is working it just doesnt see my wlan essid here at home. mint. slackware.arch and every other sees it. just not ubuntu
What frequency band and standard is the AP using?
2.437GHz channel 6. it stands on automatic. if I change channel the network is unstable.
I'm just checking the obvious things first, bear with me! Is the AP using 40MHz channels (HT a.k.a. 802.11n) ?
OK, so unlikely to be a 'n' thing then. Is the SSID hidden?
At the terminal do you get any result from "sudo iwlist wlan0 scan" (assuming the interface is called wlan0)
no. doesnt show up
I'm hot on this - I spent the entire morning reconfiguring my hostapd 802.11n into n-mode and checking it from the laptop that has an Intel 4965abgn card.
so no go... was the same with 12.04
Is the WLAN card PCI or USB?
Can you check this for me to find its PCI ID: "lspci -nn | egrep -i '(net|eth|wire)'
That's great... now do it again with "lspci -nn" so we can see the PCI Vendor:Product ID :)
great thanks, let me do a quick bit of research
What's the driver? bcrmsmac ?
hmmm. not sure.. or bwl
try lspci -nnvv | grep -A 15 'BCM'
http://pastebin.com/72a1yR7U
The "wl" driver is the Broadcom proprietary driver; did you try the Linux-included brcmsmac previously?
no
I'm assuming you installed the proprietary driver using the package bcmwl-kernel-source ?
yes
